question: Question_04_(a)
statement:
The following discrete dynamical system describes the yearly migration
of wild horse populations among three areas R, G, and B. Let
\emph{r(t)}, \emph{g(t)}, and \emph{b(t)} be the sizes of the horse
population in areas R, G, and B respectively at the
\emph{t\textsuperscript{th}} year.

\begin{align*}
x(t+1) &= \begin{bmatrix} r(t+1) \\ g(t+1) \\ b(t+1) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/3 \\
r(t)/2 + g(t)/3 + b(t)/2 \\
g(t)/3 + b(t)/6
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/3 \\ 1/2 & 1/3 & 1/2 \\ 0 & 1/3 & 1/6 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} r(t) \\ g(t) \\ b(t) \end{bmatrix} \\
&= Ax(t)
\end{align*}

Where the Markov matrix \emph{A} describes how the horses move among
these areas from one year to the next. The 1st column indicates that
each year 1/2 of the horses in area R remain in area R and 1/2 will
migrate to area G. The 2nd column shows that horses in area G will be
evenly distributed in the three areas one year later. The 3rd column
implies that, of the horses in area B, 1/3 will migrate to area R, 1/2
will migrate to area G, and only 1/6 will remain in area B.

We assume that no horses are lost and no new horses are added and that
initially (i.e. at \emph{t = 0}), there are a total of 350 horses all
located in area B. Thus $\vec x(0) = [0\ 0\ 350]^T$.

\textbf{(a)} Show that \emph{λ\textsubscript{3} = 1} is an eigenvalue of
\emph{A}. Then, find the other two eigenvalues \emph{λ\textsubscript{1}}
and \emph{λ\textsubscript{2}}.
sols:
The eigenvalues are given by the formula

$det(A-\lambda * I) = \left| \begin{array}{ccc}
a_{1 1} - \lambda & a_{1 2} & a_{1 3} \\
a_{2 1} & a_{2 2} - \lambda & a_{2 3} \\
a_{3 1} & a_{3 2} & a_{3 3} - \lambda \end{array} \right| = 0$

Doing this gives the following polynomial

$-\lambda^{3}+\lambda^2+\frac{1}{36}\lambda-\frac{1}{36} = 0$

The values we get are $\lambda = 1,\frac{1}{6},\frac{-1}{6}$

These are the eigenvalues of Matrix A and it shows that 1 is an
eigenvalue
